Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Transforming Building Structural Resilience through Innovation in Steel Diaphragms

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
America relies on a robust and resilient building stock to minimize harm to its citizens and damage to its economy due to extreme natural hazards such as earthquakes and hurricanes. In the past, structural engineers have focused their attention on creating stronger, more ductile, more reliable lateral-resistance systems that can be used within the walls of buildings to resist the extreme demands associated with these natural hazards. Comparatively little attention has been paid to the role of the floor systems of buildings in resisting these demands. The floor diaphragm acts as a critical element that distributes the demands developed in a building during an extreme event to the lateral-resistance systems and eventually to the building foundation. Steel deck, i.e., thin corrugated steel panels typically with concrete fill, forms one of the most commonly used diaphragm elements in multi-story steel buildings. This project has as its objectives: to develop fundamental understanding of steel deck diaphragms as structural systems integrated within the overall building performance, to develop improved strategies for accurate modeling of floor systems within three-dimensional building models, and to develop new solutions for steel deck diaphragms that enhance the overall structural resilience of buildings.

Current lack of knowledge about floor diaphragm systems impedes a needed evolution for building design approaches from focusing on two-dimensional frame design to enabling creative solutions within three-dimensional building design. The utilization of the diaphragm as an energy dissipating system has not been harnessed nor optimized in buildings. This project will develop a series of building archetypes appropriate to steel deck diaphragms. An integrated experimental program will be conducted at the connection and diaphragm scale, including novel non-contact measurement schemes for revealing damage and deformations during testing, to bridge critical knowledge gaps that currently impede three-dimensional modeling and design of buildings. To explore new solutions for energy-dissipating diaphragms, this project will perform testing of structural fuses and develop prototypes for integrating these fuses into steel diaphragm systems. This project will also complete high fidelity material and geometric nonlinear finite element models to enable detailed investigations of the flow of forces in diaphragms and between the diaphragm and all connected components. A series of lower fidelity, reduced order models will be developed, appropriate for whole building analysis of selected building archetypes. Formal optimization of the role of the diaphragm in building response, including a novel two-level optimization scheme, will be performed. Taken together, these activities will provide a significant advancement in the state-of-the-art for design of building diaphragms. Through a comprehensive outreach effort with industry, the findings will be transferred to engineers and utilized to improve the structural resilience of the nation's buildings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Buildings are a critically important part of our nation’s infrastructure. This award examined a feature of steel framed buildings: the concrete-filled steel deck floors and bare steel deck roof that have seen only limited study. Bare steel deck attached to joists is utilized extensively as the roof in single story buildings. During earthquakes and windstorms the lateral loads that develop must be distributed by the roof to the walls. This distribution of shear in the plane of the roof is commonly referred to as diaphragm action and the roof system as the diaphragm. We conducted cyclic tests that isolated the role of the attachment between the steel deck and the joists in the roof and simulated the behavior of the diaphragm in typical buildings, and ascertained what roof detailing provides beneficial ductility for the building during earthquakes. Compositing our tests and simulations with all available data we developed definitive guidance for engineers to model these systems. With this knowledge we created novel layouts: deck geometry and thickness, orientation, attachments, etc. of steel deck roof diaphragms using ideas from formal topology optimization. We were able to show orders of magnitude improvement in the performance of bare steel deck roof diaphragms. We also extended this optimization tool to provide insights on diaphragm design for non-rectangular buildings.

Concrete-filled steel deck attached to beams and girders with shear studs is the most common floor system in multi-story steel framed buildings. Similar to roofs, during lateral loads, the floors must act as diaphragms and distribute the lateral load to the portions of the walls that stiffen the building and carry the demands to the ground. The critical connecting pieces between the diaphragm and the frame are the shear studs – small steel elements that are welded through the deck to the beams below and provide a load path from the diaphragm forces in the concrete fill to the building frame. Our team conducted novel cyclic tests on shear studs in diaphragms and documented the strength, stiffness, deformation capacity, and ductility of this vital element. We augmented the cyclic shear stud tests with cyclic full-scale concrete-filled steel deck diaphragm tests and examined the impact of typical design decisions related to concrete weight, concrete thickness and fire rating, concrete reinforcement, shear stud position and spacing, and additional details. The results provide experimental benchmarks necessary for engineers modeling full buildings and demonstrated definitively the response for concrete-filled steel deck under different limit states: from those governed by the concrete-fill to those driven by the shear stud detailing.   

All of our experimentation and collection of existing data provided input into a series of three-dimensional steel-framed building models. These models considered two primary steel bracing systems: buckling restrained braces, and concentric braces; three different diaphragm design options; and building heights of 1, 4, 8 and 12 stories. All of the models were fully three-dimensional and included nonlinear representations for the floor and roof diaphragms – a novel model feature compared with existing work. The models were exercised under a variety of increasing earthquake hazards to assess the impact of diaphragm design choices on the building performance. The results demonstrated that new diaphragm design approaches, that explicitly include inelasticity and yielding in the diaphragm, could provide equivalent or better performance than existing design. However, the models also showed that three-dimensional building response can be more complex than commonly assumed and current failure criteria, utilized by engineers, may not be well-suited to accurately predict building failure. We augmented our detailed models with a broad study using simplified models that included nonlinear walls and diaphragms and were able to demonstrate that care must be taken when predicting the demands on building components where inelasticity is allowed in both the diaphragm and the walls. 

Building codes and standards have been positively impacted by this award. Methods to predict the demands on roof diaphragms during earthquakes have been improved, validated, and adopted by both the model NEHRP standard and the next edition of ASCE 7. Further, new performance-based and prescriptive detailing procedures were developed and adopted in NEHRP and AISI S400 that specifically reward new roof construction techniques with improved ductility, and at the same time provide a safe design for traditional construction. In addition, prediction of seismic demands for concrete-filled steel deck floors has been improved in ASCE 7 and predictions for capacity improved in AISI S310. For existing buildings, this research demonstrated and quantified the extent to which roof and floor steel deck diaphragms can be utilized to dissipate energy in an earthquake and provided engineers with new guidance in AISC 342 to account for this during seismic assessment. Taken together this award provided comprehensive reform to the manner in which steel deck diaphragms are designed and assessed going forward.
